summary: Renly: Arya, you want to learn to fight? Meet my Kingsguard, Brienne. Screw gender roles. You ladies are going to be the most...
body:
Renly: Arya, you want to learn to fight? Meet my Kingsguard, Brienne. Screw gender roles. You ladies are going to be the most badass women in Westeros.

Renly: You want a new sword? Remember my nephew, Gendry? He’s a smith! He’s also in love with you.

…

A beautiful AU where Renly lived and becomes besties with our favorite assassin and definitely teases Arya and Gendry ALL the time.

summary: Do you think that there is any significance in the third child of every family? Like Jon is Aegons third child, Dany is Aerys...
question: Do you think that there is any significance in the third child of every family? Like Jon is Aegons third child, Dany is Aerys third child, Arya is Ned’s third child, and Tyrion is Tywins third child. There seems to be so much importance on the characters who were the third kid. Maybe not Arya as much since she’s the only one whose mother didn’t die in childbirth with her but she’s still so important to the story line that it makes me wonder.
answer:
Oh, definitely. The third child is one that does not inherit the title, nor is ever the heir at any point (until the firstborn has a child of their own). Like Benjen Stark or Loras Tyrell, the third child has to seek their own glory by their own merits, otherwise they fall into the shadows of their elder siblings. In short, the third child isn’t remarkable or particularly remembered unless they take the initiative to make something of themselves.

Which is exactly what Jon, Dany, Arya and Tyrion are all about. Jon is a special case, given he never knew his siblings, but it very much applies to him re: Robb and even hypothetically with Aegon who would have been the Crown Prince - not Jon himself.

It reinforces the idea of them being outcasts or destined to never surpass their siblings - but in fact, they’ve all defied expectations.

Regarding Arya’s mother not dying in childbirth - true, that’s a marked difference from the rest. But every parallel doesn’t need to be exactly alike. In the same way that Tyrion doesn’t have a beast of his own, or Bran isn’t a third child, or Dany doesn’t warg the way Jon, Arya or Bran do, it’s about what such a parallel offers to the characters themselves.

Arya’s mother did not die in childbirth, but she still grew up feeling insecure about her mother’s affections. She still ends up motherless, a lost child, desperately wishing for her family. Not unlike the rest, really.

Regardless of the specifics of their situation, I think it ultimately comes down to the fact , Jon, Arya, Dany, Tyrion - and Bran - started from a position in the shadows and are emerging quickly to the top. The unexpected heroes, if you will.

title: 6SS: Sansa & Arya: Drinks
body:
Arya had been waiting for Sansa to get at the bar for a little while, when she felt a presence by her side, turning to look who it was, she realized it was her sister, “You’re late, you know?”

“I know, I’m sorry, work kept me late,” Sansa flagged the bartender, “vodka and cranberry please!”

Arya raised her eyebrows surprised, Sansa rarely drank hard alcohol, “Damn Sans, must have been a day from hell for you to start with vodka!”

“It’s my boss,” Sansa groaned, putting her head in her hands, “She hates me, I’m sure of it; she just… wants me to fail so she can gloat about it - joke’s on her though, it actually motivates me to do better.”

Arya patted her sister’s shoulder, “That’s the spirit! Show her who’s boss!”

“Technically, it’s her,” Sansa smirked at her sister, “but thanks for the support, now let’s drink, have some fun and forget about that awful woman!”

summary: Another Gendrya Excerpt This comes from chapter 7 “La Di Da” “This isn’t about you!” She was truly shouting now, but she didn’t...
body:
Another Gendrya Excerpt

This comes from chapter 7 “La Di Da”

“This isn’t about you!” She was truly shouting now, but she didn’t care. “None of this is any of your business!”

“This is absolutely my business,” he retorted. “You are my business, whether you like it or not.”

You’re not even my real brother. She hated herself a little for even thinking it, but the fog of anger that had settled over her mind was blurring the line between okay and unacceptable.

“You know what? I’ll drive myself home,” she said, turning around to walk into her bedroom and closing the door behind her with more force than was really necessary.

She tried to ignore him as she sprayed her plants and fed her fish one last time but he wasn’t letting up.

“Arry, come on. We’re both going home anyway. We should just go together. You don’t even have to talk to me if you don’t want to.” She didn’t want to.

summary: So I'm curious...How do you think it ends ?? Who ends up on the Iron Throne ?? Who die ?? Who survive ?? Like I thought I was...
question: So I'm curious...How do you think it ends ?? Who ends up on the Iron Throne ?? Who die ?? Who survive ?? Like I thought I was rational until I made a list on my phone and realized I had a lot of survivors considering the history of this show...Would you mind sharing ??
answer:
I think it ends with the Throne destroyed and with that, what it represented, I think that the line “I’m going to break the wheel” has a meaning and it’s destroying what the Iron Throne represents.

The official poster that it’s the Iron Throne and Drogon makes me believe that maybe I’m in the right way (or I hope so lol). In the books many times it’s said that Drogon is Balerion reborn and Daenerys is represented as a female version of Aegon I Targaryen, Aegon created the Seven Kingdom as we know them today and Balerion’s fire was the one who helped create the Iron Throne. I think it would be poetic if Daenerys and Drogon ended what Aegon and Balerion started.

So, who ends in the Iron Throne? No one, there’s no Iron Throne anymore, instead it will rise an assembly with the representants of the noble houses, it’s not perfect but it’s a step in the right direction. I think the Westeros is going to be too much destroyed to be ruled by just one person, it needs the help of every powerful family. Maybe there’s one or two more representative persons, but that’s how I imagine the ending.

And I wish for the survival of my faves, like everyone right? That is Daenerys, Arya, Sansa, Missandei…(yes, girl power!)

I think characters that are going to die are Cersei, Euron, Jaime, Tormund, Pod, Varys, Melisandre, the Mountain, Jorah, Theon, Beric and Tyrion. Some of this death are based of spoilers and leaks I read and others in what I believe.

I know many people believe that the show is going to kill mostly everyone because of the line “If you think this story has a happy ending you haven’t been paying attention”, but I think it’s an error to think like that, they are not going for a Disney ending but neither a traumatical ending were everyones dies, there are going to be a lot of deaths but mostly soldiers and minor characters deaths. We’ll see a lot of destruction but the ones who will suffer more are the common people and not the main characters.

I know a lot of people believe that Daenerys is going to die (or some people want her to die). I don’t think she’ll die (and I don’t want it either), but she won’t be queen. I don’t see her destiny is to die in the battle against the NK, or in childbirth like some people say. She’ll take part of that assembly because her role is to help people and she needs to be in a position of power to do that.
Daenerys is the Stallion who mounts the world (she united the dothrakis under the same khalasar, she’s leading them to the end of the earth -crossed the sea, fight against the NK and his army-), she’s the princess who was promised, Azor Ahai reborn, born amidst smoke and salt (she was born in Dragonstone during the worst storm in decades and she was reborn in the fire), the red comet was seen after she was reborn in the fire and she woke the dragons from the stones and the dragons are the burning sword, Lightbringer. Her destiny is to lead the people against the darkness and after that, help to rebuild the world, that’s my theory of why she won’t die.

About the other characters I think/want will survive I don’t have such compelling reasons, but Arya is a survivor, Sansa for example, they completely changed her storyline, they took the storyline from other character for her in the show, that’s why I don’t think she’ll die, they took a lot of trouble with her and I don’t see Missandei dying, she’s too important in terms for the future, the only one who knows so many languages and would be able to establish good relationships with other parts in the world when Westeros will need help to rebuilt itselfs.

Her destiny is to lead the people against the darkness and after that, help to rebuild the world, that’s my theory of why she won’t die.

About the other characters I think/want will survive I don’t have such compelling reasons, but Arya is a survivor, Sansa for example, they completely changed her storyline, they took the storyline from other character for her in the show, that’s why I don’t think she’ll die, they took a lot of trouble with her and I don’t see Missandei dying, she’s too important in terms for the future, the only one who knows so many languages and would be able to establish good relationships with other parts in the world when Westeros will need help to rebuilt itselfs.
trail.content:
I think it ends with the Throne destroyed and with that, what it represented, I think that the line “I’m going to break the wheel” has a meaning and it’s destroying what the Iron Throne represents.

The official poster that it’s the Iron Throne and Drogon makes me believe that maybe I’m in the right way (or I hope so lol). In the books many times it’s said that Drogon is Balerion reborn and Daenerys is represented as a female version of Aegon I Targaryen, Aegon created the Seven Kingdom as we know them today and Balerion’s fire was the one who helped create the Iron Throne. I think it would be poetic if Daenerys and Drogon ended what Aegon and Balerion started.

So, who ends in the Iron Throne? No one, there’s no Iron Throne anymore, instead it will rise an assembly with the representants of the noble houses, it’s not perfect but it’s a step in the right direction. I think the Westeros is going to be too much destroyed to be ruled by just one person, it needs the help of every powerful family. Maybe there’s one or two more representative persons, but that’s how I imagine the ending.

And I wish for the survival of my faves, like everyone right? That is Daenerys, Arya, Sansa, Missandei…(yes, girl power!)

I think characters that are going to die are Cersei, Euron, Jaime, Tormund, Pod, Varys, Melisandre, the Mountain, Jorah, Theon, Beric and Tyrion. Some of this death are based of spoilers and leaks I read and others in what I believe.

I know many people believe that the show is going to kill mostly everyone because of the line “If you think this story has a happy ending you haven’t been paying attention”, but I think it’s an error to think like that, they are not going for a Disney ending but neither a traumatical ending were everyones dies, there are going to be a lot of deaths but mostly soldiers and minor characters deaths. We’ll see a lot of destruction but the ones who will suffer more are the common people and not the main characters.

I know a lot of people believe that Daenerys is going to die (or some people want her to die). I don’t think she’ll die (and I don’t want it either), but she won’t be queen. I don’t see her destiny is to die in the battle against the NK, or in childbirth like some people say. She’ll take part of that assembly because her role is to help people and she needs to be in a position of power to do that.
Daenerys is the Stallion who mounts the world (she united the dothrakis under the same khalasar, she’s leading them to the end of the earth -crossed the sea, fight against the NK and his army-), she’s the princess who was promised, Azor Ahai reborn, born amidst smoke and salt (she was born in Dragonstone during the worst storm in decades and she was reborn in the fire), the red comet was seen after she was reborn in the fire and she woke the dragons from the stones and the dragons are the burning sword, Lightbringer. Her destiny is to lead the people against the darkness and after that, help to rebuild the world, that’s my theory of why she won’t die.

About the other characters I think/want will survive I don’t have such compelling reasons, but Arya is a survivor, Sansa for example, they completely changed her storyline, they took the storyline from other character for her in the show, that’s why I don’t think she’ll die, they took a lot of trouble with her and I don’t see Missandei dying, she’s too important in terms for the future, the only one who knows so many languages and would be able to establish good relationships with other parts in the world when Westeros will need help to rebuilt itselfs.

blog.name: atimefordirewolves
blog.title: "Have a biscuit, Potter"
blog.description: Sarah, 23, UK, Hufflepuff // I love Arya, Gendry, Theon, Dany, and Ginny Weasley with my whole moronic heart // #atimefordirewolves

summary: is gendry actually arya's best friend, or do you think that's been exaggerated by the fandom a bit?
question: is gendry actually arya's best friend, or do you think that's been exaggerated by the fandom a bit?
answer:
Eh, I think to an extent we exaggerate it because Arya and Gendry have never explicitly referred to each other as being best friends BUT we haven’t pulled it from nowhere. It’s just joining up very obvious dots.

Arya is very mistrustful of everyone around her due to the horrors she has had to go through - always cynical of people even when they treat her well. Within the show context, a decent example of this is actually the Brotherhood. They never mistreat her or harm her, and when they discover she’s Arya Stark they decide to protect her; they don’t let her ‘go’ at the Inn at the Crossroads, not because they’re wanting to hurt her, but because they acknowledge it is dangerous for Ned Stark’s daughter to be by herself. But Arya still doesn’t trust them.

Another good example is Hot Pie. He doesn’t do anything to imply he would ever betray Arya’s confidence - he follows her lead, trusts her, and whilst he can do very little to protect her, we know that if he could, he would. Yet Arya doesn’t trust him enough to tell her who she is; he only finds out when the Hound recognises her. Hot Pie is her friend, yet she still doesn’t trust him enough to tell him who she is, despite certainly knowing he wouldn’t betray her.

And so that takes us to Gendry - Gendry who Arya immediately forms an alliance with, Gendry who knows who she is, Gendry who Arya trusted enough to tell him who she is even when she barely knows him at all. 

“Lommy and Hot Pie can’t know. No one can know.”
“Well they won’t. Not from me.”

Arya doesn’t trust people, yet she immediately trusts him. She views him as importantly as she views her family. This is why she is so distraught when she realises he intends to leave her.

“These men are brothers. They’re a family. I’ve never had a family.”
“I can be your family.”

Book wise, their duo is even more pronounced - Arya trusts him to keep watch when she sleeps, knowing he won’t harm her. She goes to him when she needs help with things. The two are a team, who work intuitively together. She compares him with Jon in her mind, often, who we all know is the most important person to her.

After she is separated from Gendry, Arya never truly trusts anyone else again. Her identity remains hidden. She never actively chooses to tell someone who she is again. Arya never trusts anyone like she trusts Gendry.

So to summarise, before I start rambling away again - no, it’s never explicitly stated they are ‘best friends’, but logic tells you everything you need to know. Of course, there are romantic undertones going on which add other dimensions, but he is the only person beyond her family who she thinks of often, who she trusts entirely, who she jibes with like she does her brothers, who she has an unspoken trust and teamwork duo with. So yes. Gendry is quite obviously Arya’s best friend. And it’s why their reunion is going to be emotional and I’m EXCITED because they trust each other like they trust nobody else

summary: Do you think Gendry will end up Lord of Storm’s End?
question: Do you think Gendry will end up Lord of Storm’s End?
answer:
Assuming you’re asking about the tv show version, it’s certainly possible. Davos witnessed Stannis claiming Gendry as Robert’s, so that might be decent enough proof. It’s at least more concrete than “Hey, that boy sure looks freakishly like Renly.” And if being Lord of Storm’s End is Edric Storm’s endgame in the novels, that makes the chances even more likely. 

However, I don’t think Storm’s End has been mentioned for years and we don’t even know who has it now. I wouldn’t be surprised if it was eaten by the black hole that took Quaithe/ other Qarth stuff, Marya Seaworth, Robert and Cersei’s baby boy, etc. 

At the very least, I think he’ll be allowed to call himself “Gendry Baratheon” and save the name. With Robert killing Rhaegar and trying really hard to end the Targaryen line, it’d be nice to have Rhaegar’s biological son help Robert’s son restore House Baratheon.

But I’m guessing you asked me this in the hopes of Arya/Gendry stuff sooo…

I’m not gonna lie, until the credits roll on the finale, I’m going to hope that they’ll go full “My Feather Bed” and Gendry will be offered it but turn it down…. And at least imply it’s because Arya would prefer him as her “forest love” and being his “forest lass” rather than be lord and lady. Yeah, it’s fairytale-ish and fan fic-y but dammit, I’m prepared for pretty much everyone else having to “settle” and I want Arya to have the happiest ending she can manage.  

It’s actually not completely baseless:

In agot, Ned tells Arya she will marry a king someday and Arya tells him, “No, that’s Sansa.” This, of course, was written when Arya and Jon were most likely meant to end up together so that was probably foreshadowing/irony. She doesn’t necessarily reject the idea of marrying a king; it might just be that she disliked being forced onto the same path as Sansa.  

In the show, when Ned tells Arya that “you will marry a high lord and rule his castle and your sons [will essentially have way more fun than you ever will],”  she says, “No, that’s not me.” True, this might just mean Arya would never be a traditional “proper little lady.” She didn’t seem opposed to being “lord of a holdfast.”  Gendry would obviously value her as an equal and with her brains, compassion, and determination, plus the fact that she’s charming and likable, she is well suited to pretty much anything. But just because she can do something— and do it well—doesn’t mean she’d truly be happy about it. I’m great with little kids but I sure as hell don’t want to run a daycare center.

And ever since Arya talked about seeing the edge of the world with such awe, I feel like all signs point to her “being free” when this is over. Nymeria choosing to stay with her new pack rather than go back to Winterfell seems especially significant, especially when followed up with Arya saying, “That’s not you.” 

Sansa’s great childhood wish was to be a queen/great lady, and for years, only got cruel, twisted versions with Joffrey, Ramsay, Cersei and Littlefinger. Similarly, Arya would have loved to grow up traveling and meeting new people and learning combat techniques but she didn’t get to actually enjoy any of it. She was always on the run from someone trying to kill her and most of the time didn’t even know if she’d be able to get food and water or shelter. 

Just as Sansa has been making her dreams come true on her own terms, Arya deserves the same. I want her to have the chance to experience adventure without having to be afraid or hide who she is. I want her to be able to sit down and befriend random people she comes across and listen to their stories and share her own. I want her to be able to stop by to see her friends and family members without discovering that they’ve just been murdered or recently traumatized.

And Gendry is still the best choice to accompany Arya. Nymeria didn’t leave to become a lone wolf and neither would Arya. She is very sociable and generally likes being around other people, especially the members of her pack.

Plus there’s this conversation between Gendry and Davos:

Davos: I didn’t want to be a lord. I nearly didn’t accept.

Gendry: Why did you?

Davos: I did it for my son. […] I wanted him to have a better life.

Gendry: Does he?

Davos: He’s dead.

Davos and Gendry have a lot in common: They grew up in Flea Bottom, spent half their lives running from the law, and made unlikely friendships with high borns. One of the recurring themes of this series is the new generation making different/better choices than those before them. I could see Davos urging Gendry just to do what makes him happy or Gendry realizing that becoming a lord for Arya’s benefit would ultimately backfire.

Lyanna chose to pursue freedom from everyone’s expectations and a future with Robert by marrying Rhaegar and becoming a princess. Which started a war and got themselves and a whole lot of other people killed.

So perhaps Arya and Gendry will find freedom in a much less destructive way… by leaving titles behind?

 Arya and Gendry could have a nice enough life with crowns of precious metal and a castle but they’d probably be happier with crowns made of golden leaves and a cottage in the forest and I can’t help but hope that’s exactly what they get.

At the very least, I think he’ll be allowed to call himself “Gendry Baratheon” and save the name. With Robert killing Rhaegar and trying really hard to end the Targaryen line, it’d be nice to have Rhaegar’s biological son help Robert’s son restore House Baratheon.

And ever since Arya talked about seeing the edge of the world with such awe, I feel like all signs point to her “being free” when this is over. Nymeria choosing to stay with her new pack rather than go back to Winterfell seems especially significant, especially when followed up with Arya saying, “That’s not you.” 

Sansa’s great childhood wish was to be a queen/great lady, and for years, only got cruel, twisted versions with Joffrey, Ramsay, Cersei and Littlefinger. Similarly, Arya would have loved to grow up traveling and meeting new people and learning combat techniques but she didn’t get to actually enjoy any of it. She was always on the run from someone trying to kill her and most of the time didn’t even know if she’d be able to get food and water or shelter. 

Just as Sansa has been making her dreams come true on her own terms, Arya deserves the same. I want her to have the chance to experience adventure without having to be afraid or hide who she is. I want her to be able to sit down and befriend random people she comes across and listen to their stories and share her own. I want her to be able to stop by to see her friends and family members without discovering that they’ve just been murdered or recently traumatized.

And Gendry is still the best choice to accompany Arya. Nymeria didn’t leave to become a lone wolf and neither would Arya. She is very sociable and generally likes being around other people, especially the members of her pack.

Plus there’s this conversation between Gendry and Davos:

Davos: I didn’t want to be a lord. I nearly didn’t accept.

Gendry: Why did you?

Davos: I did it for my son. […] I wanted him to have a better life.

Gendry: Does he?

Davos: He’s dead.

Davos and Gendry have a lot in common: They grew up in Flea Bottom, spent half their lives running from the law, and made unlikely friendships with high borns. One of the recurring themes of this series is the new generation making different/better choices than those before them. I could see Davos urging Gendry just to do what makes him happy or Gendry realizing that becoming a lord for Arya’s benefit would ultimately backfire.

Lyanna chose to pursue freedom from everyone’s expectations and a future with Robert by marrying Rhaegar and becoming a princess. Which started a war and got themselves and a whole lot of other people killed.

So perhaps Arya and Gendry will find freedom in a much less destructive way… by leaving titles behind?

 Arya and Gendry could have a nice enough life with crowns of precious metal and a castle but they’d probably be happier with crowns made of golden leaves and a cottage in the forest and I can’t help but hope that’s exactly what they get.

trail.content_raw:
Assuming you’re asking about the tv show version, it’s certainly possible. Davos witnessed Stannis claiming Gendry as Robert’s, so that might be decent enough proof. It’s at least more concrete than “Hey, that boy sure looks freakishly like Renly.” And if being Lord of Storm’s End is Edric Storm’s endgame in the novels, that makes the chances even more likely. 

However, I don’t think Storm’s End has been mentioned for years and we don’t even know who has it now. I wouldn’t be surprised if it was eaten by the black hole that took Quaithe/ other Qarth stuff, Marya Seaworth, Robert and Cersei’s baby boy, etc. 

At the very least, I think he’ll be allowed to call himself “Gendry Baratheon” and save the name. With Robert killing Rhaegar and trying really hard to end the Targaryen line, it’d be nice to have Rhaegar’s biological son help Robert’s son restore House Baratheon.

But I’m guessing you asked me this in the hopes of Arya/Gendry stuff sooo…

I’m not gonna lie, until the credits roll on the finale, I’m going to hope that they’ll go full “My Feather Bed” and Gendry will be offered it but turn it down…. And at least imply it’s because Arya would prefer him as her “forest love” and being his “forest lass” rather than be lord and lady. Yeah, it’s fairytale-ish and fan fic-y but dammit, I’m prepared for pretty much everyone else having to “settle” and I want Arya to have the happiest ending she can manage.  

It’s actually not completely baseless:

In agot, Ned tells Arya she will marry a king someday and Arya tells him, “No, that’s Sansa.” This, of course, was written when Arya and Jon were most likely meant to end up together so that was probably foreshadowing/irony. She doesn’t necessarily reject the idea of marrying a king; it might just be that she disliked being forced onto the same path as Sansa.  

In the show, when Ned tells Arya that “you will marry a high lord and rule his castle and your sons [will essentially have way more fun than you ever will],”  she says, “No, that’s not me.” True, this might just mean Arya would never be a traditional “proper little lady.” She didn’t seem opposed to being “lord of a holdfast.”  Gendry would obviously value her as an equal and with her brains, compassion, and determination, plus the fact that she’s charming and likable, she is well suited to pretty much anything. But just because she can do something— and do it well—doesn’t mean she’d truly be happy about it. I’m great with little kids but I sure as hell don’t want to run a daycare center.

And ever since Arya talked about seeing the edge of the world with such awe, I feel like all signs point to her “being free” when this is over. Nymeria choosing to stay with her new pack rather than go back to Winterfell seems especially significant, especially when followed up with Arya saying, “That’s not you.” 

Sansa’s great childhood wish was to be a queen/great lady, and for years, only got cruel, twisted versions with Joffrey, Ramsay, Cersei and Littlefinger. Similarly, Arya would have loved to grow up traveling and meeting new people and learning combat techniques but she didn’t get to actually enjoy any of it. She was always on the run from someone trying to kill her and most of the time didn’t even know if she’d be able to get food and water or shelter. 

Just as Sansa has been making her dreams come true on her own terms, Arya deserves the same. I want her to have the chance to experience adventure without having to be afraid or hide who she is. I want her to be able to sit down and befriend random people she comes across and listen to their stories and share her own. I want her to be able to stop by to see her friends and family members without discovering that they’ve just been murdered or recently traumatized.

And Gendry is still the best choice to accompany Arya. Nymeria didn’t leave to become a lone wolf and neither would Arya. She is very sociable and generally likes being around other people, especially the members of her pack.

Plus there’s this conversation between Gendry and Davos:

Davos: I didn’t want to be a lord. I nearly didn’t accept.

Gendry: Why did you?

Davos: I did it for my son. […] I wanted him to have a better life.

Gendry: Does he?

Davos: He’s dead.

Davos and Gendry have a lot in common: They grew up in Flea Bottom, spent half their lives running from the law, and made unlikely friendships with high borns. One of the recurring themes of this series is the new generation making different/better choices than those before them. I could see Davos urging Gendry just to do what makes him happy or Gendry realizing that becoming a lord for Arya’s benefit would ultimately backfire.

Lyanna chose to pursue freedom from everyone’s expectations and a future with Robert by marrying Rhaegar and becoming a princess. Which started a war and got themselves and a whole lot of other people killed.

So perhaps Arya and Gendry will find freedom in a much less destructive way… by leaving titles behind?

 Arya and Gendry could have a nice enough life with crowns of precious metal and a castle but they’d probably be happier with crowns made of golden leaves and a cottage in the forest and I can’t help but hope that’s exactly what they get.

blog.name: thefandomsurvives
blog.description: The Blacklist, Lizzington, Game of Thrones, Jonsa, Sansa Stark, Sherlock, Molly Hooper, Harry Potter, Hermione Granger, + whatever may catch my eye

summary:
Sansa: I saw you with Gendry
Arya: 
Sansa: He was making starry eyes and calling you "m'lady"
Arya: 
Sansa: Then you punched his...
body:
Sansa: I saw you with Gendry
Arya: 
Sansa: He was making starry eyes and calling you "m'lady"
Arya: 
Sansa: Then you punched his arm and threatened to kill him
Arya: 
Sansa: So I want to know... when are you two getting married?
Arya: 
Sansa:  
Arya: New face, who dis?
